name: Linear First Order
advice: Differential Equations is largely about identification of the problem.
There'll be techniques to learn too, but knowing will be more than half the battle.

name: Seperable Equations and âˆƒ! Theorem
advice: Separation of variables is a technique that we'll keep seeing at the end of problems.
The existence and uniqueness theorem is much more crucial than it seems.
If we didn't know a solution existed, we might just be wasting time trying to find it.
If we weren't sure that solutions were unique, we couldn't trust the results from models.
Don't confuse these with the idea that the solution we get from a model must match the reality of the situation. Knowing that model solutions are reasonable is a much bigger fish.
Chaotic dynamics are still a thing even with the existence and uniqueness theorems.
There are several Existence and Uniqueness theorems in the subject, this won't be our last.

name: Special Forms and Exactness
advice: 'Homogeneous Non-Linear' and 'Homogeneous Linear' sound really similar but are pretty different.
If you didn't take Calc 3 you'll need to understand partial derivatives to get exactness. (There's some videos for this in the Calc 3 playlist.)

name: Integrating Factors and First Order Applications
advice: Integrating factors are a powerful technique, but not a time efficient one for general differential equations.
The search for an integrating factor is a little bit akin to brute force password cracking: Will it eventually work? - Yes. Will the heatdeath of the universe occur beforehand? Quite possibly...
Applications of ODEs are notoriously tricky, but nobody solves differential equations for funzies, they solve des because they'll understand the world a little better once they do.
My advice for solving applications: Don't panic and write down some math, you don't have to know how to solve it as you write it down.
Tank mixing problems come up in a ton of places in Engineering, get gud at them.

name: 2olcchodes pronounced 'ta-wak-el-chodes'
advice: I didn't make this word up. Students did. I know it's silly, but it seems to cement the concept. :shrug:
I'm also aware that the letters also aren't in that order. Complaints like this are why we can't have fun.
2olcchodes are not to be confused with 2olccnhodes (notice the additional 'n') pronounced 'ta-wak-lin-chodes', which are covered in 5.3.
This section could also be called 'Springs and Pendulums', but I saved that for the applications.

name: 2olccnhodes pronounced 'ta-wak-lin-chodes'
advice: The methods outlined in the homework for 5.3 are the basis of a technique called Method of Undetermined Coefficients.
MUDCs is an effective method for solving a great many 2olccnhodes, but I personally prefer Variation of Parameters.
If you'd like to make your own determination about this, MUDCs is covered in 5.4 and 5.5. You may well run across it in Engineering classes.
VOP is the prefered technique in my mind because it lends itself to higher order situations and is a lot easier to remember because MUDCs invlives lots of cases...

name: Midterm and Series Solutions
advice: In my mind, chapter 7 is a bit too complicated for this class, but it's an important concept, so we'll dip our toes in.
The idea of a power series solution to an equation is a pretty common basis for coding algorithms, but it's really hard to do by hand.
If you're headed into applied math, this chapter would be a really good after the course self study.

name: Laplace Transforms
advice: The Laplace transform doesn't necessarily make a problem easier, but it does shift the difficulty to algebraic techniques, which are a bit simpler.
The Laplace Transform is also the only tool we have to deal with disconinuous forces, which are encoutered everyday.
You literally cannot go to the grocery store without encountering a discontinuous forcing term.

name: IVPs and Unit Steps
advice: The whole point of this technique is to solve IVPs.
The Laplace transform relies on you having those initial values in order to solve des.
Unit step functions model switched behaviors.
If you've never seen a switch before, it's a stick that has two positions, usually one makes a thing off and the other makes the thing on.
You can think of a place you've seen a switch before right?

name: Piecewise Forcing and Dirac Deltas
advice: If you own a hammer, this is a model you need.
Given the prevalence of procussive problem solving in engineering fields, Dirac's Delta function is underappreciated.

name: Systems of Differential Equations
advice: Systems of des are far and away the most common case. It's very rare for a problem to involve a single value changing in time.
A linear algebra class is a good idea.
Interconnected tanks are really really cool.
Markov processes are another common model that feel very similar to interconnected tanks.

name: Socchodes pronounced 'Sock-Hodes'
advice: I bet you wish you'd signed up for linear... :)
Eigenpairs are super cool and generally fairly hard to find.
If you're in Linear I bet you can see why we'd want a Diagnalization right about now...
After you've calculated a few eignepairs

name: More Socchodes
advice: There's a real rabbit hole to fall down here about the algebraic and geometric multiplicity of eigenvalues.
We're going to avoid it for the most part, but I'd feel bad not pointing it out.

name: Review for Final
advice: You got this.
You've got gud.
Seriously though, good work for making it to the end. I really appreciate all the effort.
